metadata.mods.abstract.1: From McClung Des: This picture, made from Myrtle Point on Mt. LeConte, is considered one of the most typical views of the Great Smoky Mountains National Park that has been made. It shows the ruggedness, the forest-clad features, and also the elements at play. The knife-like ridges of the Greenbrier wilderness area are seen, with Mt. Guyot, Mt. Chapman, and other peaks along the state line under the drifting clouds. When clouds hang low over the Great Smokies, with a low temperature, dazzling hoar frost will almost always form on the trees and vegetation, sometimes an inch or so thick. Hoar frost is shown here on the nearby trees

Primitive Grist, or Tub Mill, Le Conte Creek
metadata.modsabstract: When the Great Smoky Mountains National Park was established, there were a score of Mill Creeks within the park's boundaries. The name "Mill" was applied to these streams because grist mills had been built on those streams in the pioneer days. In the foothills most of the mills used the picturesque over-shot water wheels. But, back up nearer the headwaters of the streams the mills were smaller and were powered by the home-made vertical turbines. In these, fan-like blades were carved from the same piece of wood that was used for the vertical shaft. The capacity of such mills was quite small; about a bushel, or a tub full. Hence, the name "tub" mill. Note the man carrying his "turn" of corn, just left of the tiny mills.

metadata.modsabstract: Throughout the coves and valleys of the Great Smokies there are hundreds of primitive cabins of which this one is typical.  The little building to the left is known as the "smokehouse".  It is where the year's supply of pork is cured and stored.

Rising from a base of 1292 feet above sea level to an elevation of 6593 feet is majestic Mt. LeConte, Eastern America's "tallest" mountain, and grandstand of the Great Smokies.  Mt. LeConte has a range in elevation of 5301 feet, or a mile and 21 feet, in a little more than a five-mile radius.  It is, therefore, the "tallest" peak--highest above its own immediate base--east of the Mississipi River.  The 1292-foot elevation is at Gatlinburg, Tennessee, part of which is seen in the foreground of the picture.  Gatlinburg is the location of Park headquarters.  This view can be seen from the highway of the 100 mile loop, via Sevierville, Gatlinburg, Maryville, etc.

metadata.modsabstract: One of the most interesting and picturesque features on the spectacular Tennessee side of the Newfound Gap Highway is the Loop-Over Bridge.  At this unique engineering feature -- which replaced four dangerously sharp curves -- the roadway passes under a beautiful masonry bridge, thus gaining the necessary elevation for the continued gentle climb up the mountain.  The Chimney Tops are seen in the background.

metadata.modsabstract: Newfound Gap, elevation 5045 feet, is where the road of the same name crosses the main chain of the Great Smokies.  There is ample room for parking hundreds of cars in this high gap.  At the right is seen the starting point of the impressive Skyway, highly scenic park road, that swings gracefully near the crest of the mountain and climbs gently to an elevation of 6311 feet, near the top of 6642 foot Clingmans Dome -- highest peak in the park.  A glimpse of this peak is seen in the left background.

metadata.modsabstract: Pioneer cabins located throughout the foot-hill section of the Great Smoky Mountains National Park add a picturesque interest to the park.  While many of the cabins are still occupied -- the owners having exercised their privilege to retain a life-time lease when selling their land and homes to the park -- poorer types that have been vacated have been removed so the surroundings can soon become "natural" again.  Some of the better examples of mountain architecture, however, are being restored and will be preserved as a part of the park museum projects.

metadata.modsabstract: The Loop-Over, seen here from the Chimney Tops, is one of the most unique features on the thrillling Tennessee side of the Newfound Gap Highway.  Here the road makes one complete circle instead of four sharp extremely dangerous curves that were on the old road at this point.  M. Le Conte is seen in the background of this picture.  The small peak with the wisp of cloud is sometimes called "West-Point" and the next broader peak is "Cliff-Top".  The next ones in order are "High-Top", the highest point and "Myrtle-Point", the grandstand of the Smokies.

metadata.modsabstract: Most of the streams in the Great Smokies are entirely safe for drinking purposes. The water flows from deep-shaded mountain sides, free from human contamination, and it is well aerated as it dashes wildly down the steep mountain sides. Even during the hottest days of summer, the water is so cold that it will cause one's hands to ache if held in the water for a few minutes.

metadata.modsabstract: Abrams Falls, on Abrams Creek, is in the western part of the Great Smoky Mountains National Park, three miles down the creek from Cades Cove.  The Falls are reached by a trail that starts at Oliver's in the Cove, and follows approximately along Abrams Creek.  Another approach is to follow the old Cooper Road, which leaves the Cove just north of Oliver's, for some three miles or to the radio aerial, then turn abruptly left and follow the trail about a mile and a half to the falls.  The pool at the bottom of Abrams Falls provides the best swimming in or near the Great Smoky Mountains National Park.  Expert divers are unable to reach bottom just below the falls.  The pool then tapers up gradually until it is from ankle-deep to knee-deep at the lower edge.

metadata.modsabstract: There are few, if any, more thrilling climbs in the Great Smoky Mountains National Park than the short but extremely rough ascent of the Chimney Tops, seen here.  These jagged peaks rise precipitously above the west prong of Little Little Pigeon River and the Newfound Gap Highway. For about five miles along this spectacular motor road the motorist is looking up to these peaks. Then, just before reaching the Tennessee-North Carolina state line at Newfound Gap, he may look down upon them. There is no graded trail or road up to the Chimney Tops, this being one of the peaks left for the enjoyment of the increasing numbers of hikers who like to "rough it."

metadata.modsabstract: One of the prettiest displays of water in the Great Smokies is at Laurel Falls.  Here the word Falls is used in the plural advisedly, for there are really two separate and distinct falls -- one immediately above and the other immediately below the trail.  In other words, the trail crosses the beautiful stream on a fifteen foot shelf that separates the two falls.  In this view we see only the upper falls.  The lower unit is equally interesting, and just as large.  This beauty spot is only 1.3 miles from the paved Scenic Loop Highway at Fighting Creek Gap.  Along the trail there are many fine views and a number of impressive rock cliffs.

metadata.modsabstract: While the top of the bald is grass clad, the edges of Gregory supports the finest known native stands of the exquisite flame azaleas. The colors range from a pure white, through the yellows, to a deep scarlet. These mountain-top meadows are not a result of "timber line", since higher peaks nearby are tree clad to their very tip tops. Scientists are not ageed on the cause of these balds, but all agree that they are not caused by timber lines. Many people fear that, since grazing has been stoppped, the balds may grow up in briars then revert to forest.

metadata.modsabstract: From Parsons Bald, near the southwestern end of the Great Smoky Mountains National Park, one can see the grassy dome of Gergory Bald (in the left background) and Rye Patch, on Long Hungry Ridge (the grassy open space in the right background). These balds are quite common on high peaks and ridges in the southwestern half of the park. Many people have assumes that they are "above timberline". This is not the case, however, as the size of the trees at the edge of the bald indicates. The phenomenon is explained as being the result of grazing over long periods -- first by deer, and later by domestic animals. These grassy balds were highly prized grazing lands for many years before the area became a national park.

This jagged point is no more rugged that other near-by peaks along the Sawtooth section of the Great Smokies. Its extreme ruggedness, however, was exposed to view when that spot was swept by fire in 1925. Dense forests give an apparent smoothness to equally precipitious points near this pinturesquely named feature. Mt. Le Conte is seen in the right background.

metadata.modsabstract: One of the most pleasing and picturesque spots in the Great Smoky Mountains National Park is the mountain bordered level section known as Cades Cove, situated at the western end of the Tennessee side of the park.  The cove is about six miles long and from two to four miles wide, and is completely surrounded by high mountains, those in the background are called "The Great Smoky Range" and form the Tennessee-North Carolina State line.  The only outlet is the circuitous route of Abrams Creek, the Stream which drains the cove and its surrounding wall of mountains.  For many years the road seen here in the foreground was the only passable inlet for vehicles.  The National Park Service has already built a second motor road, and plans another.

metadata.modsabstract: There is a picturesque quality to these typical mountain homes throughout the foothills of the Great Smoky Mountains. The swinging bridge, seen here, is the generally used method for foot travel in crossing the streams. Vehicles and domestic animals had to ford the streams or stay on the same side. Quite a number of cabins in the park are still occupied, -- the owners having exercised their privilege to retain a life-time lease when selling their land and homes to the park, - but the poorer types that have been vacated have been removed so the surroundings can soon become "natural" again. This cabin is between Pigeon Forge and Gatlinburg, near the highway.

metadata.modsabstract: There are few, if any, more thrilling climbs in the Great Smoky Mountains National Park than the short but extremely rough ascent of the Chimney Tops, seen here.  These jagged peaks rise precipitously above the west prong of Little Little Pigeon River and the Newfound Gap Highway.  For about five miles along this spectacular motor road the motorist is looking up to these peaks.  Then, just before reaching the Tennessee-North Carolina state line at Newfound Gap, he may look down upon them.  There is no graded trail or road up the Chimney Tops, this being one of the peaks left for the enjoyment of the increasing numbers of hikers who like to "rough it."

About half way up the south side of Mt. Le Conte is a huge over-hanging cliff, which has long been known as Alum Cave. During the Civil war, salt peter was mined, on a small scale, under the bluff, and the natives confused this salt-peter with alum, thence the name "Alum Cave". This spectacular spot is on the foot trail from Newfound Gap highway to the top of Mt. Le Conte, and is about two and half miles from "Grassy Patch" where the cars should be parked when taking this hike. It is a favorite destination for naturalist and is extremely interesting to park visitors.

metadata.modsabstract: Unmatched varieties of wild flowers constitute the greatest attractions of the Great Smokies.  In this picture we see the Catawbiense (purple) Rhododendrons bordering the Alum Cave Trail to Le Conte.  This trail is one of the most attractive in the park, for if you hike only a short distance or the full length to the top there are points of interest all along the way.  This view shows a close-up of what the mountaineers call "slicks" when in full bloom.  These "slicks" appear quite smooth from a distance but unless a trail has been cut through them the hiker will find it very difficult to navigate and anything but smooth going.

metadata.modsabstract: Along the streams in the Great Smokies--as here along the west prong of Little Pigeon River--are many beautiful groves of hemlock trees. Growing in a surrounding of deciduous or hardwood trees, the dark green of the hemlocks do much to enliven the winter landscapes. They also add a note of variety at other seasons, and particularly in the autumn when the other trees are vieing one with another for a gaudy display of colors.

Throughout the coves and deep-cut gorges of the Great Smoky Mountains National Park are many stately tulip trees of large dimensions. It is not uncommon to find these trees, often called poplars, or yellow poplars by lumberman, that are six and seven feet in diameter and are 100 or more feet to the first limb. In comparison with the giant redwoods or sequoias of the west coast these are insignificant, they are quite large in comparison with other trees of the eastern part of the country.
